metadata.title: 50-State Wiretap and Recording Consent Laws
metadata.description: Comprehensive database of state wiretapping and recording consent laws for the United States
metadata.disclaimer: This information is for educational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. Laws may change; consult an attorney for specific legal guidance.
sources: Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press

states.name: Alabama
states.criminalPenalty: Class A misdemeanor, up to 1 year, $6,000 fine
states.summary: One-party consent required. Recording in public places without privacy expectation does not require consent.

states.name: Alaska
states.summary: One-party consent. Third-party interception without consent prohibited.

states.name: Arizona
states.summary: One-party consent. Interception without being a party is a felony.

states.name: Arkansas
states.criminalPenalty: Class A misdemeanor, up to 1 year, $2,500 fine
states.summary: One-party consent for recording conversations.

states.name: California
states.criminalPenalty: Wobbler (misdemeanor/felony), up to 1 year jail or state prison, $2,500-$10,000 fine
states.summary: All-party consent required for confidential communications. Violations can be misdemeanors or felonies.

states.name: Colorado
states.summary: One-party consent. Disclosure of illegally obtained info is a felony.

states.name: Connecticut
states.criminalPenalty: Class D felony, up to 5 years, $5,000 fine
states.summary: All-party consent for telephone. One-party for in-person conversations.

states.name: Delaware
states.criminalPenalty: Class E felony, up to 5 years, $10,000 fine
states.summary: Conflicting laws - follow all-party consent for safety.

states.name: Florida
states.criminalPenalty: Third-degree felony, up to 5 years, $5,000 fine
states.summary: All-party consent required. Illegally obtained recordings inadmissible.

states.name: Georgia
states.summary: One-party consent. Parents may record minor children's conversations.

states.name: Hawaii
states.criminalPenalty: Class C felony, up to 5 years, $10,000 fine
states.summary: One-party consent if not for criminal/tortious purposes.

states.name: Idaho
states.summary: One-party consent. Recording non-party conversations is a felony.

states.name: Illinois
states.summary: All-party consent for private conversations. Open recording of police in public protected.

states.name: Indiana
states.summary: One-party consent. Unlawful interception is a felony.

states.name: Iowa
states.summary: One-party consent for recording.

states.name: Kansas
states.summary: One-party consent for audio recording.

states.name: Kentucky
states.summary: One-party consent. Eavesdropping without consent is a felony.

states.name: Louisiana
states.criminalPenalty: Felony, 2-10 years at hard labor, $10,000 fine
states.summary: One-party consent. Harsh penalties - up to 10 years.

states.name: Maine
states.criminalPenalty: Class C crime, up to 5 years, $5,000 fine
states.summary: One-party for most; all-party for dressing rooms/bathrooms.

states.name: Maryland
states.summary: All-party consent for audio recording. Currently a felony.

states.name: Massachusetts
states.summary: Strictest law - crime to secretly record even as a party. Open recording permitted.

states.name: Michigan
states.summary: Law unclear - court rulings suggest participant may record without others' consent.

states.name: Minnesota
states.summary: One-party consent. Significant penalties.

states.name: Mississippi
states.summary: One-party consent for recording.

states.name: Missouri
states.summary: One-party consent. Illegal recording and disclosure are felonies.

states.name: Montana
states.summary: Recording allowed if warning given. Relatively minor penalties.

states.name: Nebraska
states.criminalPenalty: Class IV felony, up to 2 years, $10,000 fine
states.summary: One-party consent.

states.name: Nevada
states.summary: All-party for telephone; one-party for in-person. Unique dual standard.

states.name: New Hampshire
states.summary: All-party consent. Third-party interception is felony.

states.name: New Jersey
states.summary: One-party consent. Recording for criminal purposes illegal regardless.

states.name: New Mexico
states.summary: One-party consent.

states.name: New York
states.criminalPenalty: Class E felony, up to 4 years
states.summary: One-party consent. 2025 legislation proposes changing to all-party.

states.name: North Carolina
states.summary: One-party consent. Public officials face enhanced penalties.

states.name: North Dakota
states.criminalPenalty: Class C felony, up to 5 years
states.summary: One-party consent.

states.name: Ohio
states.summary: One-party consent. Substantial civil damages.

states.name: Oklahoma
states.summary: One-party consent. Third-party recording is felony.

states.name: Oregon
states.summary: Split rule: one-party for phone, all-party for in-person.

states.name: Pennsylvania
states.criminalPenalty: Third-degree felony, up to 7 years, $15,000 fine
states.summary: Strictest two-party law. Recording, disclosing, and using illegally obtained comms all felonies.

states.name: Rhode Island
states.summary: One-party consent.

states.name: South Carolina
states.summary: One-party consent. Significant civil damages.

states.name: South Dakota
states.summary: One-party consent.

states.name: Tennessee
states.summary: One-party consent. Penalties vary by communication type.

states.name: Texas
states.summary: One-party with lawful purpose. Harshest penalties - up to 20 years.

states.name: Utah
states.summary: One-party consent. Recording as participant expressly permitted.

states.name: Vermont
states.statute: No state statute; federal law applies
states.summary: No state law - federal one-party consent applies.

states.name: Virginia
states.summary: One-party consent. Recordings may be inadmissible if others unaware.

states.name: Washington
states.criminalPenalty: Gross misdemeanor, up to 1 year, $5,000 fine
states.summary: All-party consent. Consent implied if one party announces recording.

states.name: West Virginia
states.summary: One-party consent.

states.name: Wisconsin
states.summary: One-party consent.

states.name: Wyoming
states.summary: One-party consent if reasonable privacy expectation.

federalLaw.note: Federal law allows recording with one-party consent. For interstate communications, the stricter state standard applies.

specialNotes.interstateRecording: When recording between different states, the stricter consent standard applies. If one party is in a two-party state, obtain all-party consent.
specialNotes.publicPlaces: Most states exempt recordings in public places where no reasonable expectation of privacy exists.
specialNotes.lawEnforcement: All states provide exceptions for law enforcement with proper authorization.
